title: 109_s1260
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005" requires consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2719) is amended to specify conditions for Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations to engage in gaming activities. The amendment to Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act allows exceptions for Indian lands in Oklahoma without reservations to establish gaming establishments after consultation with relevant authorities within 60 miles to ensure no negative economic impact. The Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005 requires the concurrence of the Governor and legislative body of the State where a gaming activity is proposed to be conducted. The land for gaming activities must have a primary nexus to the Indian tribe located within the State. This does not apply to land where a gaming facility is already in operation before the Act's enactment. The geographic, social, and historical nexus to land of an Indian tribe is determined for land owned by or held in trust for the benefit of the tribe, located within designated geographical areas where financial assistance and social services are provided, including land on or near a reservation. The Indian tribe must reside in a group predominantly composed of its members within its historical geographical area or within the boundaries of its last recognized reservation in a different state. The Indian tribe must conduct gaming activities on one contiguous parcel of Indian lands, as specified in the Act. SEC. 3. TRIBAL GAMING ORDINANCES. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2710) is amended to specify conditions for conducting class II gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to specify conditions for conducting class II gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes, including activities on the land and specific requirements for conducting gaming on Indian lands. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to specify conditions for conducting class II gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes, including activities on the land and specific requirements for conducting gaming. The definition of "State" is clarified to include the Governor and legislative body of the State. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to specify conditions for conducting class II gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes, including activities on the land and specific requirements for conducting gaming. The definition of "State" is clarified to include the Governor and legislative body of the State. Investigation and approval processes are outlined in Section 4. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to grant powers to the Chairman and the Commission regarding the approval or disapproval of individuals or entities with the highest financial interest in gaming activities. The Commission is required to identify these entities and conduct background investigations. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to authorize the Commission to conduct background investigations on tribal gaming commissioners, key employees, and primary management officials to ensure compliance with gaming ordinances. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to authorize the Commission to conduct ongoing oversight of tribal gaming commissioners, key employees, and primary management officials. Commission funding is increased from $8,000,000 to $16,000,000. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require Indian tribes to submit an environmental impact statement and obtain the Secretary's consent before using Indian lands for gaming. Existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulation are not affected by this Act.
